item.description: This recording of our Devoxx 2016 talk will give you an overview of what Serenity/JS is about and how the Screenplay Pattern can make the design of an automated test more scalable and easier to change.

item.title: From Scripts to Serenity
item.description: In this series of 3 tutorials you'll learn how to write automated tests and generate comprehensive test execution reports in the context of an Angular application, exercised using Serenity/JS, Cucumber, Protractor, Selenium WebDriver and Chai.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: From Scripts to Serenity: Speaking the right language
item.description: As applications get more complex, it becomes a priority for test automation systems to capture and clearly express business intent, to ensure that the most important functionality of the system is sufficiently covered. They need to be easy to scale to multiple projects and teams, and all this while keeping maintenance costs to a minimum.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: From Scripts to Serenity: Writing what you'd like to read
item.description: In the previous article we looked at how taking the scripting approach to test automation can result in a code base that's brittle and difficult to maintain. We've also talked about how the Page Object(s) pattern succeeded in addressing some of those problems, but also introduced some new ones.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: From Scripts to Serenity: Making the tests speak for themselves
item.description: In the last tutorial we looked at the basics of writing acceptance tests that are focused, readable and free of accidental complexity. Those characteristics make even the most sophisticated test suites easy to understand, maintain and extend. We've also introduced the concepts behind the Screenplay Pattern, an innovative new way of designing automated test systems.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Overview
item.description: Serenity/JS is an acceptance testing library that improves and expands the capabilities of Protractor-based test suites.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Reporting
item.description: Building on the shoulders of Serenity BDD and years of research into patterns of scalable acceptance testing and effective communication, Serenity/JS provides the most comprehensive reporting capabilities of all the functional testing libraries based on the Node.js platform.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Prerequisites
item.description: Serenity/JS is a Node.js module. To help you ensure maximum stability, it relies on a recent, {{ book.package.engines.node }} Long-Term Support (LTS) version of the Node.js platform.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Retrofitting
item.description: In the most basic scenario, Serenity/JS can act as an integration layer between the Protractor test runner and either of the Cucumber or Mocha test frameworks.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Installation
item.description: To fully benefit from Serenity/JS and to implement test scenarios using the Screenplay Pattern and either Cucumber or Mocha you'll need the core serenity-js module, but also a couple of other dependencies.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Serenity/JS can be configured using the Protractor configuration file - protractor.conf.js, which then becomes the first argument of the Protractor command line test runner you invoke to execute the tests:
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Cucumber
item.description: Cucumber is a popular collaboration tool used by many teams practicing Behaviour-Driven Development to capture requirements in a form of concrete examples and executable specifications.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Working with Cucumber
item.description: Cucumber is a popular collaboration tool used by many teams practicing Behaviour-Driven Development to capture requirements in a form of concrete examples and executable specifications.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Automating Cucumber Scenarios
item.description: So that a Cucumber scenario can be executed, the Given/When/Then steps expressed in plain language need to be somehow associated with the test automation code.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Executing Cucumber Scenarios
item.description: Cucumber scenarios are executed using the Protractor command line interface, and since it's installed as a local module, we need to define an npm script to access it.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Mocha
item.description: Mocha is a feature-rich JavaScript test framework running on Node.js.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Working with Mocha
item.description: Mocha is a popular JavaScript test framework, most often used for unit and integration testing. However, Mocha's lightweight syntax and excellent support for executing asynchronous test scenarios, combined with the power of Serenity/JS, make it a good choice for writing functional acceptance tests that can either drive the development of new systems or quickly provide a safety net around the legacy ones.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Automation
item.description: Let's see how Serenity/JS can be plugged into a Mocha test scenario, and how to use the describe and it blocks effectively so that both the scenarios and the reports capture the domain knowledge and vocabulary.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Executing Mocha Scenarios
item.description: Mocha scenarios are executed using the Protractor command line interface, and since it's installed as a local module, we need to define an npm script to access it.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Design
item.description: In this part we'll talk about some of the details of designing test scenarios.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: The Screenplay Pattern
item.description: The Screenplay Pattern is a user-centred model, which helps you shift the focus of automated acceptance tests from low-level interactions with the system to thinking about who the users of your system are, what is that they want to achieve by their interaction with your system and how exactly they're going to do it.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: The Stage
item.description: The Stage is the central place where the action of a test scenario takes place, and where the actors perform their activities.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak

item.title: Assertions
item.description: Serenity/JS does not force you to use any particular assertion library, so you can use any that supports promises.
item.dc:creator: Jan Molak
